hints.label: thm-permutation-symmetry
hints.title: Permutation Invariance
hints.content:
250: :label: thm-permutation-symmetry
251: 
252: The Geometric Gas transition operator $\Psi$ is **exactly invariant** under the action of the symmetric group $S_N$. For any permutation $\sigma \in S_N$:
253: 
254: $$
255: \Psi(\sigma(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot) = \sigma \circ \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)
256: 
257: $$
258: 
259: Equivalently, the transition kernel satisfies:
260: 
261: $$
262: P(\mathcal{S}_{t+1} | \mathcal{S}_t) = P(\sigma(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) | \sigma(\mathcal{S}_t))
263: 
264: $$
hints.raw_directive:
247: The most fundamental symmetry is the **exchangeability** of walkers.
248:

hints.label: proof-thm-permutation-symmetry
hints.content:
270: :label: proof-thm-permutation-symmetry
271: 
272: We verify invariance at each stage of the algorithm.
273: 
274: **Stage 1: Measurement and localized statistics**
275: 
276: The alive-walker empirical measure is permutation-invariant:
277: 
278: $$
279: f_k[\sigma(\mathcal{S})] = \frac{1}{k}\sum_{j \in A_k} \delta_{(x_{\sigma(j)}, v_{\sigma(j)})} = \frac{1}{k}\sum_{i \in \sigma(A_k)} \delta_{(x_i, v_i)} = f_k[\mathcal{S}]
280: 
281: $$
282: 
283: since $\sigma$ permutes the alive set: $\sigma(A_k) = A_k$ (the set is unchanged, only indices are relabeled).
284: 
285: The localized weights $w_{ij}(\rho)$ depend only on pairwise distances:
286: 
287: $$
288: w_{\sigma(i)\sigma(j)}(\rho) = \frac{K_\rho(x_{\sigma(i)}, x_{\sigma(j)})}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_{\sigma(i)}, x_{\sigma(\ell)})} = \frac{K_\rho(x_i, x_j)}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)} = w_{ij}(\rho)
289: 
290: $$
291: 
292: Therefore, all localized moments are invariant:
293: 
294: $$
295: \mu_\rho[f_k[\sigma(\mathcal{S})], Q, x_{\sigma(i)}] = \mu_\rho[f_k[\mathcal{S}], Q, x_i]
296: 
297: $$
298: 
299: **Stage 2: Fitness potential**
300: 
301: By invariance of the Z-scores, the fitness potential satisfies:
302: 
303: $$
304: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k[\sigma(\mathcal{S})], \rho](x_{\sigma(i)}, v_{\sigma(i)}) = V_{\text{fit}}[f_k[\mathcal{S}], \rho](x_i, v_i)
305: 
306: $$
307: 
308: **Stage 3: Cloning operator**
309: 
310: The companion selection kernel $\mathbb{C}_\epsilon(\mathcal{S}, i)$ depends only on the algorithmic distances $d_{\text{alg}}(i, j)$, which are permutation-invariant when indices are relabeled consistently.
311: 
312: The cloning probability depends only on the fitness values, which are invariant by the above.
313: 
314: **Stage 4: Kinetic operator**
315: 
316: The BAOAB integrator acts independently on each walker with state-independent noise, hence commutes with permutations.
317: 
318: **Stage 5: Status refresh**
319: 
320: The boundary indicator $\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}}(x_i)$ is permutation-invariant.

hints.label: thm-translation-equivariance
hints.title: Conditional Translation Equivariance
hints.content:
347: :label: thm-translation-equivariance
348: 
349: Suppose the reward function $R(x, v)$ and domain $\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ satisfy:
350: 
351: $$
352: R(x + a, v) = R(x, v), \quad x + a \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}
353: 
354: $$
355: 
356: for some $a \in \mathbb{R}^d$. Then the transition operator is **translation-equivariant**:
357: 
358: $$
359: \Psi(T_a(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = T_a \circ \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot)
360: 
361: $$
hints.raw_directive:
344: Euclidean translations interact with the reward function and domain boundaries.
345: 
346: :::{prf:theorem} Conditional Translation Equivariance
347: :label: thm-translation-equivariance
348: 
349: Suppose the reward function $R(x, v)$ and domain $\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ satisfy:
350: 
351: $$
352: R(x + a, v) = R(x, v), \quad x + a \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}
353: 
354: $$
355: 
356: for some $a \in \mathbb{R}^d$. Then the transition operator is **translation-equivariant**:
357: 
358: $$
359: \Psi(T_a(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = T_a \circ \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot)
360: 
361: $$
362:

hints.label: proof-thm-translation-equivariance
hints.content:
367: :label: proof-thm-translation-equivariance
368: 
369: **Measurement stage**: Since $R(x + a, v) = R(x, v)$, the reward Z-scores are invariant:
370: 
371: $$
372: Z_\rho[f_k[T_a(\mathcal{S})], R, (x_i + a, v_i)] = Z_\rho[f_k[\mathcal{S}], R, (x_i, v_i)]
373: 
374: $$
375: 
376: The distance channel uses the algorithmic projection $\varphi(x, v) = (x, \lambda_v v)$. Under translation:
377: 
378: $$
379: d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_i + a, v_i), \varphi(x_j + a, v_j)) = \|(x_i + a) - (x_j + a)\| = \|x_i - x_j\| = d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_i, v_i), \varphi(x_j, v_j))
380: 
381: $$
382: 
383: Therefore distance measurements are invariant, and the fitness potential satisfies:
384: 
385: $$
386: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k[T_a(\mathcal{S})], \rho](x_i + a, v_i) = V_{\text{fit}}[f_k[\mathcal{S}], \rho](x_i, v_i)
387: 
388: $$
389: 
390: **Kinetic stage**: The BAOAB integrator uses the force $F(x) = \nabla R(x)$. If $R(x + a) = R(x)$, then $F(x + a) = F(x)$, so:
391: 
392: $$
393: \Psi_{\text{kin}}(T_a(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = T_a \circ \Psi_{\text{kin}}(\mathcal{S}, \cdot)
394: 
395: $$
396: 
397: **Status refresh**: By assumption, $x + a \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$, so survival status is equivariant.

hints.label: rem-warning-translation-symmetry-breaking
hints.title: Breaking of Translation Symmetry
hints.content:
404: :class: warning
405: 
406: **Generic case**: For bounded domains $\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ with walls, translation symmetry is **broken** except for special directions (e.g., periodic boundaries).
407: 
408: **Periodic domains**: If $\mathcal{X} = \mathbb{T}^d$ (the $d$-dimensional torus) and $R(x + e_i) = R(x)$ for lattice vectors, then full $\mathbb{Z}^d$ translation symmetry holds.

hints.label: thm-rotation-equivariance
hints.title: Rotational Equivariance
hints.content:
416: :label: thm-rotation-equivariance
417: 
418: Suppose:
419: 1. The domain is rotationally symmetric: $Rx \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ for all $R \in SO(d)$
420: 2. The reward is rotation-invariant: $R(Rx, Rv) = R(x, v)$ for all $R \in SO(d)$
421: 
422: Then the Geometric Gas is **rotationally equivariant**:
423: 
424: $$
425: \Psi(\mathcal{R}(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \mathcal{R} \circ \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot)
426: 
427: $$
hints.raw_directive:
413: ### 3.3. Rotation and Orthogonal Symmetries
414: 
415: :::{prf:theorem} Rotational Equivariance
416: :label: thm-rotation-equivariance
417: 
418: Suppose:
419: 1. The domain is rotationally symmetric: $Rx \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ for all $R \in SO(d)$
420: 2. The reward is rotation-invariant: $R(Rx, Rv) = R(x, v)$ for all $R \in SO(d)$
421: 
422: Then the Geometric Gas is **rotationally equivariant**:
423: 
424: $$
425: \Psi(\mathcal{R}(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \mathcal{R} \circ \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot)
426: 
427: $$

hints.label: proof-thm-rotation-equivariance
hints.content:
433: :label: proof-thm-rotation-equivariance
434: 
435: **Algorithmic distance**: Under rotation, the Sasaki metric transforms as:
436: 
437: $$
438: d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(Rx_i, Rv_i), \varphi(Rx_j, Rv_j)) = \|Rx_i - Rx_j\| = \|x_i - x_j\| = d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_i, v_i), \varphi(x_j, v_j))
439: 
440: $$
441: 
442: using $R^T R = I$ for orthogonal matrices.
443: 
444: **Localization kernel**: The Gaussian kernel depends only on distances:
445: 
446: $$
447: K_\rho(Rx_i, Rx_j) = \exp\left(-\frac{\|Rx_i - Rx_j\|^2}{2\rho^2}\right) = K_\rho(x_i, x_j)
448: 
449: $$
450: 
451: Therefore localized moments and Z-scores are rotation-invariant.
452: 
453: **Kinetic operator**: The force $F(x) = \nabla R(x)$ transforms covariantly:
454: 
455: $$
456: F(Rx) = R \nabla R(x) = R F(x)
457: 
458: $$
459: 
460: The noise is isotropic (covariance $\sigma_v^2 I$), hence rotation-invariant.

hints.label: thm-fitness-scaling
hints.title: Fitness Potential Scaling Symmetry
hints.content:
484: :label: thm-fitness-scaling
485: 
486: The fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}$ is **scale-invariant** under simultaneous rescaling of the exponents and floor parameter. Specifically, for any $c > 0$:
487: 
488: $$
489: V_{\text{fit}}[\alpha, \beta, \eta](x, v, S) = V_{\text{fit}}[c\alpha, c\beta, \eta^c](x, v, S)^{1/c}
490: 
491: $$
hints.raw_directive:
481: ### 3.4. Scaling Symmetries
482: 
483: :::{prf:theorem} Fitness Potential Scaling Symmetry
484: :label: thm-fitness-scaling
485: 
486: The fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}$ is **scale-invariant** under simultaneous rescaling of the exponents and floor parameter. Specifically, for any $c > 0$:
487: 
488: $$
489: V_{\text{fit}}[\alpha, \beta, \eta](x, v, S) = V_{\text{fit}}[c\alpha, c\beta, \eta^c](x, v, S)^{1/c}
490: 
491: $$

hints.label: proof-thm-fitness-scaling
hints.content:
497: :label: proof-thm-fitness-scaling
498: 
499: The fitness potential is:
500: 
501: $$
502: V_{\text{fit}} = \eta^{\alpha + \beta} \exp(\alpha Z_r + \beta Z_d)
503: 
504: $$
505: 
506: Under the rescaling $\alpha \to c\alpha, \beta \to c\beta, \eta \to \eta^c$:
507: 
508: $$
509: (\eta^c)^{c(\alpha + \beta)} \exp(c\alpha Z_r + c\beta Z_d) = \eta^{c(\alpha + \beta)} \exp(c(\alpha Z_r + \beta Z_d)) = \left[\eta^{\alpha+\beta} \exp(\alpha Z_r + \beta Z_d)\right]^c
510: 
511: $$

hints.label: thm-irreversibility
hints.title: Time-Reversal Asymmetry
hints.content:
527: :label: thm-irreversibility
528: 
529: The Geometric Gas is **not time-reversible**. There exists no time-reversal operator $\mathcal{T}$ such that:
530: 
531: $$
532: \mathcal{T} \circ \Psi \circ \mathcal{T}^{-1} = \Psi^{-1}
533: 
534: $$
hints.raw_directive:
524: Unlike conservative physical systems, the Geometric Gas is **irreversible**.
525: 
526: :::{prf:theorem} Time-Reversal Asymmetry
527: :label: thm-irreversibility
528: 
529: The Geometric Gas is **not time-reversible**. There exists no time-reversal operator $\mathcal{T}$ such that:
530: 
531: $$
532: \mathcal{T} \circ \Psi \circ \mathcal{T}^{-1} = \Psi^{-1}
533: 
534: $$
535:

hints.label: proof-thm-irreversibility
hints.content:
540: :label: proof-thm-irreversibility
541: 
542: **Time-reversal in Hamiltonian systems** requires velocity inversion: $\mathcal{T}(x, v, s) = (x, -v, s)$. We show this does not reverse the Geometric Gas dynamics.
543: 
544: **Cloning operator breaks time-reversal**: The cloning gate compares fitness values and creates discontinuous jumps:
545: 
546: $$
547: (x_i, v_i) \to (x_j, v_j) \quad \text{if } V_{\text{fit}}(j) > V_{\text{fit}}(i)
548: 
549: $$
550: 
551: Under velocity inversion:
552: 
553: $$
554: \mathcal{T}(x_i, v_i) = (x_i, -v_i)
555: 
556: $$
557: 
558: But the fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)$ depends on the **unaveraged** velocity through the localized Z-score of the algorithmic distance. Inverting velocities changes the fitness landscape, hence changes which cloning events occur.
559: 
560: **Companion selection is non-reversible**: The companion distribution $\mathbb{C}_\epsilon(\mathcal{S}, i)$ weights by $\exp(-d_{\text{alg}}^2/(2\epsilon^2))$. Under time reversal, companions would need to be selected using the **reversed distances** from the future state, which is impossible.
561: 
562: **Entropy production**: The cloning operator strictly increases the fitness-weighted concentration (see `03_cloning.md`, Keystone Lemma). This is a **monotone decrease** in entropy relative to the QSD, violating time-reversal symmetry which would require entropy to be conserved.

hints.label: prop-h-theorem
hints.title: H-Theorem for Geometric Gas
hints.content:
568: :label: prop-h-theorem
569: 
570: Let $H(f_t | \pi_{\text{QSD}})$ denote the relative entropy (Kullback-Leibler divergence) of the swarm distribution $f_t$ to the QSD. Then:
571: 
572: $$
573: \frac{d}{dt} H(f_t | \pi_{\text{QSD}}) \le -\kappa_{\text{total}} H(f_t | \pi_{\text{QSD}})
574: 
575: $$
576: 
577: where $\kappa_{\text{total}} > 0$ is the exponential convergence rate from `08_emergent_geometry.md`.
hints.raw_directive:

567: :::{prf:proposition} H-Theorem for Geometric Gas
568: :label: prop-h-theorem
569: 
570: Let $H(f_t | \pi_{\text{QSD}})$ denote the relative entropy (Kullback-Leibler divergence) of the swarm distribution $f_t$ to the QSD. Then:
571: 
572: $$
573: \frac{d}{dt} H(f_t | \pi_{\text{QSD}}) \le -\kappa_{\text{total}} H(f_t | \pi_{\text{QSD}})
574: 
575: $$
576: 
577: where $\kappa_{\text{total}} > 0$ is the exponential convergence rate from `08_emergent_geometry.md`.
